Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Understanding Temporal Variation in Primate Communities: Integrating Data from Extant and Fossil Species

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The distribution of species across the globe is influenced by several factors including climate, habitat, evolutionary history, and interactions with other organisms. Research on species distribution has primarily focused on modern climate variation and species distributions. In this project, a novel combination of paleontological and modern ecological data will be used to examine how past climate patterns and competition among mammals have contributed to current primate biodiversity. As habitat loss and fragmentation are occurring worldwide, research investigating the factors determining primate biodiversity has implications for conservation management and maintaining the integrity of tropical forest ecosystems. Obtaining a better understanding of how primate distributions change through time and in response to changing environments will inform models for predicting shifts in primate ranges and community structure for future climates and habitat changes. The project will include the development of a database and web-based science education resources, and training of students from traditionally under-represented populations in the STEM fields. Students will gain important skills in data management and analyses that can subsequently be used in a wide variety of future career paths.

The project seeks to examine primate community phylogenetic and trait structure across space and through time with abiotic and biotic factors suggested to cause the changing distributions and adaptations of primate species. The project is unique because fossil species locations and traits will be integrated with extant community data for macro-ecological and evolutionary analyses. Some of the questions addressed will be: Do communities found in similar environments, but on different continents, converge on the same structures? Do climate patterns from the Miocene through the present influence primate community structure? Do the presence and diversity of non-primate mammals that are potential primate competitors impact primate community structure? Are trait and phylogenetic structures of fossil primate communities predicted by climatic characteristics? The research proposed in this project will address topics that are central to understanding the modern and past distribution and coexistence of primates and other mammals. Using a community-level approach is essential for understanding how species interact to impact the evolution of each other's behavior, ecology, and morphology. Obtaining a better understanding of how primate communities change through time and in response to changing environments will inform models for predicting future shifts in primate distributions and community structure related to climate and habitat change.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We created a large dataset of modern and fossil mammals from tropical and temperate communities to address questions critical for understanding the distribution, co-existence, and adaptations of primates and other large bodied mammals. These data include large mammalian species found at modern localities in Asia, Madagascar, and South America. For Africa, we added temperate communities in the north and south of the continent, as well as fossil assemblages that include mammalian species at sites encompassing millions of years of evolutionary history. Both modern and fossil databases include each species? body size, dietary preference, and substrate type (e.g., water, trees, land, etc.). Unsurprisingly, we found that modern mammalian community structure is controlled by modern and past climate, the distinctive history of the animals in each area, and the influence of humans on their habitats. A more surprising outcome was that these structural factors have differing levels of importance on different continents.

In Africa, the fossil mammal communities are similar?but not identical? to the modern communities in the types of species present, that is, there are many extremely large mammals including primates, carnivores, and ungulates who have no modern equivalent. For example, large sabretooth cats became extinct but there is no modern mammal that has assumed their ecological role. Similarly, very large leaf-eating monkeys existed in the past but there is no modern counterpart in today?s communities. On the other hand, there are few fossil communities that do not correspond with some modern locality?s habitat and climate. Through detailed examination of the changes through time in these communities, we can see how fundamental controlling factors?such as habitat, climate, and interactions with other species?influenced the evolution of lineages such as baboons and human ancestors. More broadly, we have created the largest dataset of this type of information, offering potential for the data to be used by others to address a range of other research questions.

A fundamental focus of this project has been on scientific research training for graduate and undergraduate students. We have had four graduate students and four undergraduate students work on the project, all of whom are women who are under-represented in STEM, and some of whom are also online students who normally do not have access to opportunities for research experience. The students learned new skills in Excel, practiced various analyses on fossil localities, and presented their results during our virtual lab meetings. We are planning to create a web site so that other students, as well as interested members of the general public, can access the data and examine for themselves the differences between mammal communities spatially between continents, and though time.
